title: [FEATURE] Skia Starter Project
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem?

Problem: It is extremely difficult to get started building cross-platform with SkiaSharp (or really building anything at all with it).

After all these years, there still doesn't seem to be a starter solution for building cross-platform Skia apps. The samples in this repo don't build easily and aren't structured correctly for this, nor do they take the right approach for handling dependencies.

### Describe the solution you would like

I'd like to be able to open VS, create new project, and select "Cross Platform Skia". This should set me up with a solution containing a shared render project, and a project per native platform, each referencing the shared render project. Prefer HW accel setups.

This seems like a pretty prime use case for Skia and .NET.

If you can't create a VS template for this, then a zip file I can download with this setup would be appreciated. It would definitely be helpful in the immediate term. I just want to be able to nuget restore, build, and run. Then start adding my own paint code.

### Describe alternatives you have considered

I have explored getting this to work with the samples in this repo (no go, multiple build errors) and with AI (which can't seem to get it right either).

### Additional context

Every 6 months or so, for the last several years (I think), I pop in here to see if this one basic setup scenario has been addressed. So far, no. Today, I wasted an hour or two trying to get some things up and running. No go. So much time wasted just trying to get hello world. Extremely frustrating in 2025.

### Code of Conduct

- [x] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct

comments.author: mattleibow
comments.body:
Thanks for your interest in the project. 

When using SkiaSharp, you can install the SkiaSharp.Views package and then get a view for any platform/framework. 

There should be a PaintSurface event that you can handle to draw. 

I will still have a look at a tutorial. A template should not be needed as there is just the package and then add the view.

comments.author: EisenbergEffect
comments.body:
From my experience in open source (going on 20 years), adoption usually hinges less on how “done” a project is and more on two basics:

- A clear, easy way to get started
- Documentation that answers the first few questions

Even when a project is early/alpha, people will try it if those two things exist. When they don’t, many potential users simply bounce without leaving feedback.

If you’re open to one high-impact improvement, I’d suggest a single, easy-to-find “Getting Started” page that shows the recommended way to create a new cross-platform SkiaSharp solution with:
- a shared runtime library, and
- platform-specific hosts.

If you want to go a step further, a Visual Studio template (“File → New…”) plus a short guide pointing to it would remove a lot of friction for new users.

Also, I want to acknowledge the community side. A healthy community is critical to open-source adoption, and it’s part of the onboarding path. I did notice there’s a Discord badge and that GitHub Discussions are enabled, which is great, but they’re not very discoverable from the “Using SkiaSharp” section. A short “Getting Started” block there that links to the walkthrough/template and to “Where to ask questions” (Discord/Discussions) would make it much easier for new folks to get going and know where to turn when they get stuck.
